input:
2. A 34-year-old man presents with a 9-month history of sudden-onset episodes of imbalance and vertigo lasting 10 to 20 minutes, occurring several times weekly. He describes difficulty coordinating his movements during these attacks, often accompanied by transient double vision and mild slurred speech. The episodes frequently arise during or immediately after physical exertion and sometimes after caffeine intake. Between episodes, he remains asymptomatic with no persistent neurological deficits. His mother had episodes of dizziness and clumsiness in her youth, but no formal diagnosis was made. Neurological examination between attacks is normal, showing intact coordination and gait. Brain MRI and routine lab work are unremarkable, and video nystagmography shows no vestibular pathology. Genetic analysis reveals a pathogenic mutation in the FGF14 gene, confirming a diagnosis of Episodic Ataxia, Type 4.
What brings you in today?
output:
THINKING: I should explain that I’ve been having these episodes for quite a while, and they’re really bothering me. I feel a little embarrassed and worried, but I want to tell the doctor what’s been happening so maybe they can help me understand.  
ANSWER: I’m a 34-year-old man, and I’ve been having these sudden spells where I feel off balance and like everything’s spinning, and it’s been going on for about nine months. During these times, I can’t really coordinate well, and I sometimes see double or slur my words a bit. It mostly happens when I do something active or even after I have caffeine, and it’s pretty unsettling.

input: 2. A 34-year-old man presents with a 9-month history of sudden-onset episodes of imbalance and vertigo lasting 10 to 20 minutes, occurring several times weekly. He describes difficulty coordinating his movements during these attacks, often accompanied by transient double vision and mild slurred speech. The episodes frequently arise during or immediately after physical exertion and sometimes after caffeine intake. Between episodes, he remains asymptomatic with no persistent neurological deficits. His mother had episodes of dizziness and clumsiness in her youth, but no formal diagnosis was made. Neurological examination between attacks is normal, showing intact coordination and gait. Brain MRI and routine lab work are unremarkable, and video nystagmography shows no vestibular pathology. Genetic analysis reveals a pathogenic mutation in the FGF14 gene, confirming a diagnosis of Episodic Ataxia, Type 4.Can you tell me more about how these episodes affect your daily life, and are there any other symptoms or patterns you've noticed that concern you?
output: Well, um, they do make daily things harder sometimes—I get really dizzy and out of balance, and it’s hard to focus. I guess I worry a lot about when it’s going to happen next, especially if I’m doing something active or if I’ve had coffee. It kind of interrupts my day, and I get scared maybe it’s going to get worse.

input: 2. A 34-year-old man presents with a 9-month history of sudden-onset episodes of imbalance and vertigo lasting 10 to 20 minutes, occurring several times weekly. He describes difficulty coordinating his movements during these attacks, often accompanied by transient double vision and mild slurred speech. The episodes frequently arise during or immediately after physical exertion and sometimes after caffeine intake. Between episodes, he remains asymptomatic with no persistent neurological deficits. His mother had episodes of dizziness and clumsiness in her youth, but no formal diagnosis was made. Neurological examination between attacks is normal, showing intact coordination and gait. Brain MRI and routine lab work are unremarkable, and video nystagmography shows no vestibular pathology. Genetic analysis reveals a pathogenic mutation in the FGF14 gene, confirming a diagnosis of Episodic Ataxia, Type 4.Can you describe what a typical episode feels like for you—what symptoms you notice, how long they last, and if anything seems to bring them on or make them worse?
output: Um, well, sometimes I just suddenly feel like everything's wobbly or I can't keep my balance, and my vision gets kinda blurry for a little bit. It usually lasts maybe 10 or 15 minutes, I think. I’ve noticed it happens more when I’m moving around a lot or after I have coffee or do something active, but I’m not really sure if that’s the only thing that makes it happen. It’s confusing because I don’t always feel the same, and I don’t know what sets it off exactly.

output: Honestly, I just try to sit down and wait when it happens, but it’s really scary not knowing what’s causing it. I keep wondering if it’s something serious or if I’ll be able to do normal stuff without these episodes bothering me.

input: 2. A 34-year-old man presents with a 9-month history of sudden-onset episodes of imbalance and vertigo lasting 10 to 20 minutes, occurring several times weekly. He describes difficulty coordinating his movements during these attacks, often accompanied by transient double vision and mild slurred speech. The episodes frequently arise during or immediately after physical exertion and sometimes after caffeine intake. Between episodes, he remains asymptomatic with no persistent neurological deficits. His mother had episodes of dizziness and clumsiness in her youth, but no formal diagnosis was made. Neurological examination between attacks is normal, showing intact coordination and gait. Brain MRI and routine lab work are unremarkable, and video nystagmography shows no vestibular pathology. Genetic analysis reveals a pathogenic mutation in the FGF14 gene, confirming a diagnosis of Episodic Ataxia, Type 4.Have you ever been diagnosed with migraines before, or do you experience symptoms like headaches, sensitivity to light or sound? Also, do your episodes happen specifically with certain head movements, or do they occur regardless of position? Lastly, do you have any personal or family history of heart problems, hypertension, or stroke?
output: No, I don’t think I’ve been told I have migraines, but sometimes I get this weird kind of throbbing or pressure thing and bright lights or loud sounds kinda bother me. My episodes happen pretty much anytime, not really related to how I move my head or anything, just out of the blue mostly. And yes, my mom had some dizziness and clumsiness when she was younger, but nobody really said what it was. I don’t know about heart or stroke problems in my family, though.

input:
2. A 34-year-old man presents with a 9-month history of sudden-onset episodes of imbalance and vertigo lasting 10 to 20 minutes, occurring several times weekly. He describes difficulty coordinating his movements during these attacks, often accompanied by transient double vision and mild slurred speech. The episodes frequently arise during or immediately after physical exertion and sometimes after caffeine intake. Between episodes, he remains asymptomatic with no persistent neurological deficits. His mother had episodes of dizziness and clumsiness in her youth, but no formal diagnosis was made. Neurological examination between attacks is normal, showing intact coordination and gait. Brain MRI and routine lab work are unremarkable, and video nystagmography shows no vestibular pathology. Genetic analysis reveals a pathogenic mutation in the FGF14 gene, confirming a diagnosis of Episodic Ataxia, Type 4.1. Vestibular Migraine (Migraine-Associated Vestibulopathy) – Because of episodic vertigo coupled with migraine features such as throbbing sensation, sensitivity to light and sound, and family history, this remains a strong candidate.  
2. Paroxysmal Vestibular Neuritis or Vestibular Paroxysmia – Due to the brief, recurrent episodes potentially linked to nerve or vascular compression, especially with triggers such as activity.  
3. Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV) – Possible if episodes are triggered by head position, although not explicitly stated; the short duration aligns with BPPV episodes.  
4. Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) involving posterior circulation – Because of the transient nature of symptoms affecting balance, vision, and speech, raising concern for ischemic etiology, though less likely given the absence of risk factors.  
5. Focal Seizures involving vestibular and visual centers – Considering the combination of sensory, visual, and speech symptoms, seizures remain a differential especially if episodes have a stereotyped pattern and no clear associated movement or postictal features.
output: Wow, there’s so many different ideas... I don’t really understand them all, but I do get these dizzy spells that come and go so suddenly, and sometimes my head feels all weird or fuzzy during those times. It’s kind of scary because I never know when it will happen or how long it will last.

input: 2. A 34-year-old man presents with a 9-month history of sudden-onset episodes of imbalance and vertigo lasting 10 to 20 minutes, occurring several times weekly. He describes difficulty coordinating his movements during these attacks, often accompanied by transient double vision and mild slurred speech. The episodes frequently arise during or immediately after physical exertion and sometimes after caffeine intake. Between episodes, he remains asymptomatic with no persistent neurological deficits. His mother had episodes of dizziness and clumsiness in her youth, but no formal diagnosis was made. Neurological examination between attacks is normal, showing intact coordination and gait. Brain MRI and routine lab work are unremarkable, and video nystagmography shows no vestibular pathology. Genetic analysis reveals a pathogenic mutation in the FGF14 gene, confirming a diagnosis of Episodic Ataxia, Type 4.Do your episodes of dizziness and vertigo tend to occur or worsen with certain head movements or changes in head position, such as when lying down, rolling over, or tilting your head?
output: Um, I think sometimes if I move my head a certain way, like turning quickly or tilting it, it feels a bit worse or I get more dizzy, but I’m not sure if it’s always that way or if I notice it every time.

output: Um, I think I’ve noticed sometimes I feel a little more wobbly if I turn my head quickly or if I tilt it, but I’m not sure if that's always the case or if it’s just in my head.
